newsitem.title: FRENCH GUIANA: Second Ariane-5 to launch "dummy" satellites.
newsitem.headline: Second Ariane-5 to launch "dummy" satellites.

text.p: Europe's second Ariane-5 rocket, due to be launched in mid-April 1997 at the earliest, will put two "dummy" satellites into orbit after the first heavy launcher blew up last June with the loss of four scientific satellites, space officials said on Thursday.

"The objective of Ariane flight 502 is to demonstrate the rocket's capacity to launch double satellite payloads into Geostationary Transfer Orbit (GTO)," Jean-Marie Luton, director of the European Space Agency (ESA), told a news conference.
"We will launch two instrument platforms that represent satellite masses," Luton told a news conference in Paris broadcast to the ESA launch centre in French Guiana.

In a major setback for the European space programme, the first Ariane-5 exploded less than 40 seconds after lift-off on June 4. It was carrying an uninsured payload of four scientific satellites with a value of $500 million.
Specialists in Kourou said that the "dummy" satellites would cost less than $3 million.
An inquiry board investigating the explosion concluded in July that the failure was caused by software design errors in the rocket's inertial reference guidance system.

The explosion was a major setback for Western Europe's effort to maintain its position as leader in launching commercial satellites, and to launch eventually a manned mission aboard Ariane-5 for Europe's participation in the international space station Alpha.
The Paris-based Arianespace company that launches the Ariane rocket series said it would make an additional order for more flight proven Ariane-4 rockets.
The company had plannned to phase out gradually use of Ariane-4 and use exclusively Ariane-5 by the year 2000.
"This transition period has now become delicate. We have taken the decision to order more Ariane-4 rockets," Arianespace president Charles Bigot said.
"I cannot now give you an exact number but I would estimate it to be about five or six to meet the demands of our clients scheduled for launch in 1999," he added.
Arianespace has on order 22 more Ariane-4 rockets and 14 Ariane-5 rockets to service a customer backload of 42 heavy satellites to launch worth an estimated $4.1 billion.
It was scheduled to begin using Ariane-5 for its customers in early 1997 but that will now be delayed for at least a year.
